Award.AwardTitle: Future Directions for Computer Science Education: A Workshop Proposal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Stanford University will bring together faculty and researchers for a series of workshops to assess the potential for (1) expanding the number of researchers and specifically PhD students in Computer Science education research; and (2) establishing the legitimacy of computer science education research as a research discipline within CS departments at research-oriented schools. The first workshop will identify key research directions in computing education drawing from other STEM education disciplines. The second workshop will address the many concerns of how Computer Science education research can effectively be housed with CS departments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the running of two workshops to explore future directions in computing education research. The first workshop focused on identifying what are the most pressing research questions that are currently facing computing education, and that will continue to face computing education over the next five years. Workshop attendees identified five key areas: broadening participation (how to get more women and under-represented minorities into the computing pipeline at all levels), computing in K-12 (what computing experience should all students have prior to higher education), computing in STEM education (how computing can be integrated with mathematics, science and engineering education to improve student learning in both the targeted area as well as in computing), students and learning (how do students learn computing, how should we best teach computing, and how to measure student learning in computing), and tools (what needs to be built to support the other areas). 

 

The second workshop focused on institutional barriers to establishing and growing computing education research as a sub-area of computing research. Participants identified several key areas to address, including: hiring and promoting of computing education researchers, advocacy on behalf of computing education research, growing the existing community of computing education researchers (particularly among PhD students), and couching computing education research as a "disruptive technology."

 

The reports from the workshops are available at:

http://web.stanford.edu/~coopers/reports/index.html

 

Follow-on work has including the CRA requesting a white paper summarizing many of the issues in the reports, as a set of concrete action plans that can be implemented by computing departments.
